body_html:
Yeah, people use it for more than deep learning purposes, e.g. PPL (Pyro), HamIltonian Monte Carlo, or just CUDA-accelerated NumPy.
…
On Thu, Mar 8, 2018 at 12:14 gchanan ***@***.***> wrote: I'm not sure we have a plan, and I agree organization could be useful here, but why draw the barrier at nn vs non-nn, outside of THNN historical reasons? Do people use pytorch for non-nn use cases? — You are receiving this because you commented. Yeah, people use it for more than deep learning  purposes, e.g. PPL (Pyro),
HamIltonian Monte Carlo, or just CUDA-accelerated NumPy.

On Thu, Mar 8, 2018 at 12:14 gchanan ***@***.***> wrote:
 I'm not sure we have a plan, and I agree organization could be useful
 here, but why draw the barrier at nn vs non-nn, outside of THNN
 historical reasons? Do people use pytorch for non-nn use cases?

body:
Yeah, people use it for more than deep learning  purposes, e.g. PPL (Pyro),
HamIltonian Monte Carlo, or just CUDA-accelerated NumPy.

On Thu, Mar 8, 2018 at 12:14 gchanan <notifications@github.com> wrote:

> I'm not sure we have a plan, and I agree organization could be useful
> here, but why draw the barrier at nn vs non-nn, outside of THNN
> historical reasons? Do people use pytorch for non-nn use cases?
>
